statement.text: Arterial ulcers result from inadequate tissue perfusion in PAD/CLTI, characterized by painful, punched-out wounds on pressure points with pale base and minimal granulation, requiring revascularization for healing.
statement.formal: Location: Distal toes, lateral malleolus, pressure points; Characteristics: Punched-out, pale base, painful, minimal exudate; Treatment: Revascularization is primary therapy

explanation.intuition: When arteries can't deliver enough blood, the tissue at the farthest points (toes, heels) starves and dies, creating wounds that look 'punched out' and won't heal no matter how good the wound care is - the blood supply must be fixed first.
explanation.key_insight: Arterial ulcers don't heal with wound care alone - revascularization is mandatory for healing.
explanation.technical_details: Arterial ulcers develop when tissue perfusion falls below the threshold needed for cellular viability (typically toe pressure <30 mmHg or TcPO2 <30 mmHg). They appear on areas vulnerable to pressure and trauma: toes, lateral malleolus, heel, and metatarsal heads. The wound bed is characteristically pale or necrotic, dry with minimal exudate, and painful (unless neuropathy coexists). Surrounding skin may show dependent rubor and elevation pallor. Treatment centers on revascularization; wound care alone is futile without adequate perfusion.
common_misconceptions: Good wound care can heal arterial ulcers without revascularization - FALSE, perfusion is essential
Arterial ulcers are always dry - FALSE, may have exudate if infected
Arterial ulcers are painless - FALSE, typically very painful unless neuropathy present
Location alone distinguishes arterial from venous ulcers - FALSE, requires full assessment

symptoms.pain: Severe, often worse at night or with elevation

vs_venous_ulcer.location: Arterial: distal, pressure points | Venous: medial malleolus (gaiter area)
vs_venous_ulcer.appearance: Arterial: punched-out, dry | Venous: irregular, weeping

vs_neuropathic_ulcer.location: Arterial: pressure points | Neuropathic: plantar, metatarsal heads

vs_mixed_ulcer.features: Combination of arterial and venous features
vs_mixed_ulcer.abi: ABI <0.80 in patient with venous disease

diagnosis.imaging: CTA/MRA or angiography for revascularization planning

revascularization.principle: Primary treatment - wound cannot heal without perfusion
revascularization.goal: Restore straight-line flow to wound angiosome

infection_control.debridement: Drainage of abscess, removal of necrotic tissue

definition.@value: Skin ulceration caused by inadequate arterial blood supply, characterized by painful punched-out wounds requiring revascularization for healing.

presentation: Painful wound on toe or foot

learning_objectives: Identify characteristic features of arterial ulcers
Differentiate arterial from venous and neuropathic ulcers
Explain why revascularization is essential for healing
Apply appropriate diagnostic workup for arterial ulcers
clinical_pearls: No revascularization = no healing for arterial ulcers
Punched-out, painful, pressure points = think arterial
Toe pressure <30 mmHg predicts poor healing without revasc
Dependent rubor and elevation pallor are classic PAD signs
Don't waste time with wound care alone - fix the blood supply
